At-a-Glance: Tracheal mites (Acarapis woodi) infest adult bee airways, historically causing winter losses. Prevalence is lower in many regions but identification and management remain relevant.
Why it Matters: Can contribute to winter morbidity where present.
Objectives: Understand signs and confirm presence via lab/microscopy when suspected.
Support colonies through nutrition and ventilation; consider resistant stock.
Integrate with broader IPM rather than chasing rare causes.
What Good Looks Like: Loss investigations consider tracheal mites alongside varroa, nutrition, and moisture.
Stock bred for mite resistance where regional risk exists.
Clear records of sampling and outcomes.
Step-by-Step: 1) Suspect if: crawling bees in cold with disorientation, historical regional presence.
2) Confirm: submit samples or use trained microscopy; avoid assumptions.
3) Mitigate: improve winter ventilation and nutrition; consider resistant lines; follow any approved treatments regionally.
4) Review: align with varroa control and moisture management.
Seasonality & Climate: Winter clusters show signs more clearly.
Data & Thresholds: Rely on lab/official guidance for prevalence; track alongside other loss drivers.
Use trend data, not single anecdotes, to justify interventions.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Crawlers mid-winter with adequate stores -> Check moisture/ventilation -> Consider tracheal mite sampling.
Symptom: Yard-wide losses -> Prioritise varroa/DWV, then niche causes.
Symptom: Long-term problem at site -> Reassess siting and genetics.
Common Pitfalls: Over-attributing losses to tracheal mites without evidence.
Neglecting major drivers (varroa, moisture) while chasing rare ones.
Tools & Techniques: Sampling kits, microscopy or lab submission.
Safety & Compliance: Follow local approvals for any treatments.
Communications: Set expectations: confirm first, then act.
Further Reading: Historical prevalence reports and modern reviews.
Association guidance on differential diagnosis in winter losses.
Notes: Use loss investigations to improve site choices and genetics regardless of the cause.
